subtitle: (and why you should read it too)

data.text: I read Wasteland by Oliver Franklin-Wallis (and why you should read it too)
What kind of book were you reading over the weekend 👀 ?”
“The main protagonist travels worldwide 🌍 , harming people and nature right, left and centre. And very few things happen to make it stop.”
I’m probably a bit late to the party, but for anyone who hasn’t read Wasteland yet, I can’t recommend it enough.
From where your waste goes (probably travelling further than you do in a year 🚢) to who is involved in getting it to its final destination, it’s a fascinating read.
As promised, no spoilers, but here are some notes 📝 :
- In the UK, waste crimes are SO commonplace that in 2021 the environment agency and the police established a dedicated Joint Unit for Waste Crime (JUWC)
- Waste tends to be a problem for the next person. As in “I’ll move it from point A (being my location) ➡️ point B 📌 (somewhere where it is anyone’s problem but mine).
- If a product says it’s not flushable (or by using common sense, you know it’s not flushable), don’t flush it. There’s a whole chapter on the sewage system that while riveting, is also shocking.
- “Biodegradable” products aren’t always all they claim to be. Do your homework. Maybe even google 💻 “The Big Compost” experiment.
- If you’re googling the above, maybe look into Agbogbloshie on another tab.
- Are you aware of the “Repairability Index”? I wasn’t, but I’m a fan.

The depth and quality of the research are more in-depth that my short notes while the book itself is VERY readable (coming from a person who reads 25-30 fiction books 📚 yearly). That’s all I’ll say - if you read it and have opinions or want to rant, reach out 📩 .
